ProcedureOptionHelp.#cdata:
[Syntax: APREFIX=name] 
      
Specifies a prefix for naming the approximation variables. By default, APREFIX=A.
Includes principal component approximations to the transformed variables in the output data set.

[Syntax: CCONVERGE=n] 
      
Specifies the minimum change in the criterion being optimized that is required to continue iterating. 
By default, CCONVERGE=0.0.

[Syntax: CHANGE=n] 
      
Specifies the number of the first iteration to be displayed in the iteration history table. 
The default is CHANGE=1.

[Syntax: CONVERGE=n] 
      
Specifies the minimum average absolute change in standardized variable scores that is required to 
continue iterating. By default, CONVERGE=0.00001.
Computes the principal components from the covariance matrix.

Includes correlations and the component structure matrix in the output data set. By default, 
this information is not included.

[Syntax: DATA=SAS-data-set] 
      
Specifies the SAS data set to be analyzed.

Expands variables specified for OPSCORE optimal transformations to dummy variables for 
the initialization.

[Syntax: INITITER=n] 
      
Specifies the number of MAC iterations required to initialize the data before starting MTV or 
MGV iterations. By default, INITITER=0.

[Syntax: MAXITER=n] 
      
Specifies the maximum number of iterations. By default, MAXITER=30.

[Syntax: MDPREF<=n>] 
      
Specifies a multidimensional preference analysis by implying the STANDARD, SCORES, and 
CORRELATIONS options.
Specifies the optimization method. By default, METHOD=MTV.

[Syntax: MONOTONE=two-letters] 
      
Specifies the number of principal components to be computed. By default, N=2.

[Syntax: N=n] 
      
Specifies the number of principal components to be computed. By default, N=2.
Turns off computationally intensive numerical error checking for the MGV method.

Excludes all observations with missing values from the analysis, but does not exclude them from the 
OUT= data set.
Suppresses the display of all output.

[Syntax: OUT=SAS-data-set] 
      
Specifies an output SAS data set that contains results of the analysis. If you omit the OUT= option, 
PROC PRINQUAL still creates an output data set and names it by using the DATA convention.

Controls the plots produced through ODS Graphics. 
      
Syntax: 
(1) PLOTS <(global-plot-options)> <= plot-request <(options)>> 
(2) PLOTS <(global-plot-options)> <= (plot-request <(options)> <... plot-request <(options)>>)>
         
The global plot options include the following: 

FLIP |FLI
flips or interchanges the X-axis and Y-axis dimension for MDPREF plots.

INTERPOLATE | INT 
uses observations that are excluded from the analysis for interpolation in the fit and transformation plots.

ONLY | ONL
suppresses the default plots. Only plots specifically requested are displayed.

UNPACKPANEL |UNPACK | UNP
suppresses paneling in the scree plot.

ProcedureOptionToolTips.@ToolTip2: Syntax: TRANSFORMATION<(UNPACKPANEL)>                                  Plots the variable transformations. By default, multiple plots can appear in some output panels.  Specify UNPACKPANEL to display each plot in a separate panel.
ProcedureOptionToolTips.@ToolTip4: Suppresses the display of all graphics output.

ProcedureOptionHelp.#cdata:
[Syntax: PREFIX=name] 
      
Specifies a prefix for naming the principal components. By default, the names are Prin1, Prin2, ..., Prinn.

[Syntax: REFRESH=n] 
      
Specifies the number of variables to scale in the MGV method before computing a new inverse. By default, REFRESH=5.
Enables PROC PRINQUAL to use previous transformations as starting points.
Replaces the original data with the transformed data in the output data set.
Includes principal component scores in the output data set. By default, scores are not included.

[Syntax: SINGULAR=p] 
      
Specifies the singularity criterion, where 0 < p < 1.

Standardizes the principal component scores in the output data set to mean zero and variance one 
instead of the default mean zero and variance equal to the corresponding eigenvalue.

[Syntax: TPREFIX=name] 
      
Specifies a prefix for naming the transformed variables. By default, TPREFIX=T.
Specifies the standardization of the transformed variables in the OUT= data set.

ProcedureOptionToolTips.@ToolTip1: Centers the output variables to mean zero, but the variances are the same as the variances of the  input variables.
ProcedureOptionToolTips.@ToolTip2: Sets the means and variances of the transformed variables in the OUT= data set, computed over all  output values that correspond to nonmissing values in the input data set, to the means and  variances computed from the nonmissing observations of the original variables.
ProcedureOptionToolTips.@ToolTip3: Sets the means and variances of the transformed variables to the means and variances of the original  variables. This is the default.
ProcedureOptionToolTips.@ToolTip4: Standardizes the variables to mean zero, variance one.

ProcedureOptionHelp.#cdata:
[Syntax: TYPE=’text’|name] 
      
Specifies the valid value for the _TYPE_ variable in the input data set. If PROC PRINQUAL finds an 
input _TYPE_ variable, it uses only observations with a _TYPE_ value that matches the TYPE= value.

[Syntax: UNTIE=two-letters] 
      
Specifies the first and last special missing values in the list of those special missing values 
that are to be estimated with within-variable order constraints but no category constraints. The 
two-letters value must consist of two letters in alphabetical order.

StatementHelp.#cdata:
Syntax: BY <DESCENDING> variable-1 <...<DESCENDING> variable-n> <NOTSORTED>; 
      
Obtains separate analyses on observations in groups defined by the BY variables.

StatementOptionHelp.#cdata:
Specifies that the observations are sorted in descending order by the variable that immediately 
follows the word DESCENDING in the BY statement.
Specifies that observations are not necessarily sorted in alphabetic or numeric order.

StatementHelp.#cdata:
Syntax: WEIGHT variable;
      
When you use a WEIGHT statement, a weighted residual sum of squares is minimized. The WEIGHT 
statement has no effect on degrees of freedom or number of observations, but the weights affect 
most other calculations.

Syntax: FREQ variable ;
      
If one variable in the input data set represents the frequency of occurrence for other values in the 
observation, list the variable’s name in a FREQ statement. PROC PRINQUAL then treats the data set as 
if each observation appeared n times, where n is the value of the FREQ variable for the observation.

StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip1: Centers the output variables to mean zero, but the variances are the same as the variances of the input variables.
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip2: Sets the means and variances of the transformed variables in the OUT= data set, computed over all output values that correspond to nonmissing values in the input data set,  to the means and variances computed from the nonmissing observations of the original variables.
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip3: Sets the means and variances of the transformed variables to the means and variances of the original variables. This is the default.
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip4: Standardizes the variables to mean zero, variance one.
